results.title: Prince William: behind the headlines
results.brief_description: This is a probing, insightful and frank look at Prince William Windsor, son of Prince Charles and the late Princess Diana, the young man who will be the future King of England. At 18, moving into manhood and being plunged into the tumultuous environment of a scandal-ridden and emotionally scarred British monarchy, is he ready for the challenges and responsibilities that lie before him? This video reveals a side to ‘Wills’ (as his mother affectionately called him) that has rarely been seen before.

results.title: Prince Philip in the Gambia
results.brief_description: An account of the visit during the 1956-57 world tour photographed by members of the Royal Naval School of Photography. Highlights include the official welcome, a gathering of chiefs and a crocodile shoot.

results.title: Prince Philip
results.brief_description: A biographical film of H.R.H. The Duke of Edinburgh. A Prince of the Greek Royal House, H.R.H. was virtually adopted by the family of his British uncle, Lord Louis Mountbatten. It was at the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth during a Royal visit that he had an early meeting with Princess Elizabeth. The film includes footage of H.R.H. visitng Paris and Washington, tours of South Africa and Canada and closes dramatically with his declaration of allegiance to the Queen at her Coronation. Narrated by Jack Hawkins and John Arlott.

results.title: Prince of the city [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Burtt Harris and Sidney Lumet
results.brief_description: From Robert Daley’s book of the same name, “Prince of the city” is based on the real-life criminal investigation of police corruption. Treat Williams plays Danny Ciello, a member of the narcotics division of the New York police who is loyal to his profession, his colleagues, and his family. Danny is not ignorant of the petty deals and bribes that take place within the police, but like his fellow police officers, he believes the difficulties and pressures of their work require some kick-backs. Once Danny finds himself under investigation for police corruption however, he reluctantly decides to go undercover to save his career and family. What he discovers is the long-term and symbiotic relationship between the police, the Mafia and the underworld of drug trading. Visceral, thrilling and featuring a dynamic performance by Williams in the lead, “Prince of the city” is a crime film that also explores the ambiguities of loyalty and friendship. Refusing easy moralising, director Sidney Lumet has fashioned a taut thriller that is also an examination of a man’s anguish when he finds his ethical commitments result in alienation from the work and the world he loves. Danny’s choice is not between abstract notions of good and evil, but between choosing loyalty and community or justice and isolation. Lumet’s long-standing experience in filming in New York City results in a film in which the inner-city itself - decaying, dark and violent - becomes a character in the film. “Prince of the city”, though based on real life events, is one of Lumet’s most personally felt films and the care and commitment is evident from all the technical aspects to the casting of bit parts: at times it approaches documentary realism. The film won the prize as best film at the Venice Film Festival in 1981.

results.title: Prince of palms
results.creator_credit: Malayan Film Unit and A Peter Amavasi
results.brief_description: An account of Malaya’s third largest industry. The coconut palm is grown as a crop mainly for the extraction of oil from its nut, but it is put to a variety of other uses, ranging from rope-making from its fibre to the carving of ornamental containers from the shell.

results.title: Primeval survivors
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Hugh Macdonald and Greg Stitt
results.brief_description: The Tuatura is the sole survivor of a reptile species that is now confined to a few off-shore islands in New Zealand. The film is set on tiny Stevens Island, a wildlife sanctuary which is home for 100,000 of these unique reptiles.

results.title: Prime time
results.brief_description: Shows how to distinguish between prime and composite numbers by presenting a story in which a specialist in space communications helps maintain contact with intelligent life on a newly discovered planet.

results.title: Prime Suspect: the lost child
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Paul Marcus and John Madden
results.brief_description: When a 14 month old child disappears, Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren) is called in to lead the investigation. The case hits a raw nerve with Jane who is recovering from an abortion, as well as affecting DI Muddyman (Jack Ellis), for reasons he doesn’t wish to disclose. There is only one prime suspect, Chris Hughes (Robert Glenister), a recovering paedophile who is now living with a woman who has two young children. Tennison’s investigation is hampered by the lack of staff allocated to a kidnapping, the numbers increase, as does the personal involvement, when the case turns into a murder investigation. The Criminal psychologist (Stuart Wilson) who treated Hughes is convinced Hughes is incapable of murder, although he is capable of being pushed over the edge due to intense police scrutiny during the investigation. With Muddyman involved, this is a very probable scenario.

results.title: Prime suspect 3
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Paul Marcus and David Drury
results.brief_description: DCI Tennison (Helen Mirren) has made it in a man’s world and secured the position of a high ranking policewoman. In this third instalment of Lynda La Plante’s series Tennison is given the assignment of cleaning up the murky world of prostitutes, or “rent boys”, due to public pressure about the standard of morality in Soho- Operation Contract. The nature of her assignment quickly changes tack when one of the boys perishes in a suspicious fire. Strange details begin to emerge, such as forensic evidence that the victim was unconscious when the fire started and someone called an ambulance to the flat that night The suspects soon mount- the sleazy pimp, the head of a centre for troubled boys, and a respected police official. Tennison’s personal life is not without upheaval during the investigation as an old flame enters the scene, causing her to question life’s decisions. As Tennison leads her investigative team into an underworld populated by paedophiles, pornographic photography, transvestites and abuse, the shocking truth is revealed and Helen must make an important decision. Cast includes Vera Reynolds, David Thewlis, Danny Dyer, Tom Bell and Ciaran Hinds.

results.title: Prime suspect
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Don Leaver and Christopher Menaul
results.brief_description: The first episode of the award winning series written by Lynda La Plante. In the early hours of a winter morning the body of a brutally murdered young woman is discovered in a small bedsit. DCI Shefford is put in charge of the investigation, however the situation quickly changes when he suffers a massive heart attack and is replaced by the ambitious Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren). DCI Tennison soon discovers the difficulties of heading a homicide enquiry. Not only do her male colleagues resent the fact that she is a woman and do all they can to obstruct her, but the case itself is particularly difficult when it comes to charging the suspect George Marlow (John Bowe). Although Tennison and her team are convinced of the killer, they are unable to prove it until a second body is found and what started as a single murder develops into an investigation stretching back over ten years and implicating police officials. Cast includes Tom Bell, Zoe Wanamaker, John Benfield, Brian Pringle, Tom Wilkinson and a brief appearance by Ralph Fiennes.
